text: hey everybody thomas joseph here and
today i'm super excited to share with
you an answer to one of the most popular
questions that have been asked and that
is all about batter frying so to start
I'm going to share a perfect batter one
egg yolk is how you start an egg yolk
adds richness to batter which is very
important so one egg yolk in a
medium-sized bowl here I'm going to add
a half a teaspoon of salt salt for
flavor but you could certainly use any
other spices that you'd like and the
magic ingredient which is one and a half
cups of club soda it gives you lightness
and crunch those bubbles from the club
soda suspend in the batter and when you
fry it it gives you such a flaky light
batter so one and a half cups whisk this
all together my club soda is really cold
it's really helpful to use cold club
soda because it gives you an extra flaky
batter now the next ingredient is one
and a quarter cups of rice flour now you
could also use corn starch the ratios a
little bit different but rice flour and
corn starch they give a wonderful
lightness to the batter if you use
all-purpose flour you might end up with
something that's a little bit more tough
so it's worth it to try and find rice
flour give this a whisk don't over mix
because you don't want to toughen the
batter and now we're ready to fry I have
a neutral flavored oil like a safflower
oil or a canola oil up to 375 degrees in
a wide pot you can fry anything with
this batter that's the great thing about
it it's an all-purpose batter today I'm
using Cod for some nice fried fish and
what you need to do whenever you're
frying anything is dredge it in a little
bit of flour so I'm using rice flour
here again and what this does is it
helps the batter to cling on to the fish
so it acts as an adhesive almost so
dredge your fish in the batter and
whenever you're making a batter like
this it's very similar to a tempura
batter you
to make it in small batches and use it
right away don't let it sit because all
of those bubbles will go away so gently
place in your oil and as always when
you're crying don't overcrowd the pot
and the whole reason why you don't want
to overcrowd the pot whenever you're
frying is because it brings down the
temperature of the oil and that will end
up giving you a greasy batter so the
fish has been frying for about five
minutes it's perfectly cooked on the
inside it's golden brown on the outside
that batter gives a light crispy coating
to the outside of the fish and as they
come out of the oil like anything we fry
we like to give it a little bit of salt
I'm using flaky Maldon sea salt here
with a little squeeze of lemon this is
perfect keep going with the rest of your
fish until your all fried and ready to
serve enjoy guys
you
